abstract.p: In this article, a piezoelectric energy harvesting device comprises a bistable vibrating cantilever beam and a switching-type interface circuit (synchronized switching harvesting on an inductor) is proposed, and the resulting performance is compared to the traditional linear technique. It was known that the synchronized switching techniques increase efficiently the output power of the piezoelectric energy harvester for low-coupled structures. However, the traditional piezoelectric energy harvester based on a cantilever beam is only efficient at resonance. To broaden the available bandwidth, a bistable nonlinear technique was proposed. In this article, the bistable technique and synchronized switching harvesting on an inductor interface are combined together to accomplish a more efficient broadband piezoelectric energy harvester. The power flow and work cycles are adopted to simplify the analysis of the switching techniques and then summarize the increasing performance of the nonlinear piezoelectric harvester. Finally, simulation results and experimental validations show that the proposed integrated device owns larger bandwidth and collects more harvested energy.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: According to the piezoelectric direct effect, a piezoelectric material can generate electrical energy from a mechanical vibration. To collect the energy, a piezoelectric element is attached on a vibrating structure, and an interface circuit is connected to the piezoelectric element to transfer the generated energy to the load. If the collected energy is dissipated by Joule effect in a resistive load, the vibration of the structure will be reduced. This is called structural passive shunt damping (Hagood and Von Flotow, 1991). If the collected energy is stored in a capacitor or a battery, an energy recovery system is obtained. Piezoelectric energy harvesting has emerged as a prominent theme of research whose interest is growing. The advances in low-power components or design methodology have reduced the consumption of mobile devices and, therefore, allow the feasibility of self-powered autonomous electronic devices. This opens the possibility for completely self-powered devices and the notion of small generator producing enough power for low-consumption devices, like wireless sensor network (WSN). Ambient vibrations could be harvested in many different environments such as automobiles, buildings, structures (bridges and railways), and industrial machinery. Since 2002, numerous studies have been published on the topic of energy harvesting. Tang et al. (2010) and Khaligh et al. (2010) have made a long synthesis and developed a state of the art for vibration piezoelectric energy harvesting. This demonstrates the interest of researchers for this topic. The power density of piezoelectric generators harvested energy from vibrations is about 250 µW/cm3 (Roundy et al., 2003). In comparison, the power density of electrostatic also harvested energy from vibrations is about 50 µW/cm3. The vibration-to-electricity conversion can be also performed by electromagnetic transducers (Arnold, 2007; Inman and Priya, 2009), but the piezoelectric technologies have received much attention, as they have high electromechanical coupling and no requirement of an external voltage source.

In energy harvesting applications, the piezoelectric elements convert the vibration energy of the host structure into the electrical energy, and then the generated electrical energy is stored in a storage buffer. Since the piezoelectric element has large clamped capacitance, an impedance matching circuit is required to maximize the generated power. It is known that an inductor can be added to compensate the contribution of the piezoelectric clamped capacitor (Roundy et al., 2003), but it cannot be adaptive to the environmental variations, and the value of the inductance is too large in a low-frequency range. To overcome this drawback, switching-type interfaces were proposed and popularly used in recent years (Lefeuvre et al., 2004). In the switching circuits, the switches are operated synchronously with the vibration of the host structure in order to optimize the power flow.

Several synchronized switching circuit topologies and corresponding switching laws were proposed. They can be classified into two groups according to the placement of the rectifier and the active switches. The first group of the switching circuits places the switches between piezoelectric element and the rectifier, such as parallel synchronized switching harvesting on an inductor (SSHI) and series SSHI (Guyomar et al., 2005; Lefeuvre et al., 2006). This group of techniques is used to modify the waveform of the piezoelectric voltage, that is, the voltage across the piezoelectric element, in order to increase the collected power in the weakly coupled structure. The second group places the switches between the rectifier and the storage buffer, such as synchronous electric charge extraction (SECE) technique (Lefeuvre et al., 2005a). This group of techniques is used to modify the charging current flowing into the storage buffer in order to fasten the charging speed and to make a load adaptation.

The optimal resistance load of the series and parallel SSHI techniques is different (Badel et al., 2006; Chen et al., 2012; Guyomar et al., 2005; Minazara et al., 2006; Yang and Tang, 2009). The optimal load value of parallel SSHI (around mega-ohms) is higher than that of series SSHI (around 100 Ω). In SECE technique, the power output is not as high as the SSHI technique, but the power output is independent of the load. In SSHI techniques, the switching circuit only turns on at the extreme value of the displacement or at the zero crossing of velocity to shift the phase of the voltage across the piezoelectric element. These techniques are used because the piezoelectric generator is weakly coupled to the host structure, that is, only a small amount of mechanical energy is taken from the structure and converted into electricity. The electrical behavior of the piezoelectric generator with the SSHI circuit is equivalent to an operation under strong coupling conditions by increasing the output voltage.

Although the piezoelectric materials exhibit high power density, the linear piezoelectric energy harvester is efficient only when the mechanical system is excited at the resonance frequency; there is largest strain, largest vibration displacement, and maximum output power compared to work at nonresonant frequency. However, in practice, the exciting frequency of the ambient vibration source is random, and it varies within a frequency range (Roundy et al., 2003). It is impossible to excite the energy harvester at specific resonance frequency and to keep the system operating on the maximum power point. In the cantilever beam system, the quality factor is commonly very high. It causes that the device has high harvesting power only at single resonance frequency. In order to increase the power at nonresonant frequency, designing a mechanical system to work in a wide frequency range is necessary. This design concept to enlarge the frequency bandwidth is based on applying external forces. By applying an axial force, the resonant frequency of a piezoelectric cantilever beam can be successfully tuned (Leland and Wright, 2006; Zhu et al., 2008), but these methods are active techniques and the mechanical system is still operated within the linear regime. Another method consists to make a nonlinear or bistable vibration of a cantilever beam to enlarge the workable bandwidth (Ando et al., 2010; Erturk et al., 2009; Lin et al., 2010; Mann and Sims, 2009). Using simple fixed magnets, this passive technique makes the mechanical system improve the harvesting efficiency within nonresonant regime without any external power.

In this article, the performances, drawbacks, and system requirements of magnetic nonlinear piezoelectric generators combined with the SSHI technique, as shown in Figure 1(c), will be discussed. According to the comparisons with the other linear standard generator (Figure 1(a)) and linear SSHI generator (Figure 1(b)), the voltage waveform across the piezoelectric element and displacement is used to show the efficiency of the bistable piezoelectric energy harvester through the work-cycle representation. The simulation and experimental results show that the SSHI technique is advantageous over the standard interface for both linear and nonlinear cases, and the nonlinear case is advantageous over linear for both the standard and SSHI techniques. The theoretical analysis, equivalent circuit model, and simulation and experimental results will be presented in the following sections.

sec.title: Series SSHI technique
sec.p:
The schematic diagram of the full-wave bridge rectifier is shown in Figure 1(a). Figure 4(b) shows the waveforms of standard DC approach. When the absolute voltage value of the piezoelectric element vp is less than the output DC voltage VDC, the diode bridge is in open circuit. The diodes conduct and piezoelectric elements charge the load only when vp reaches load voltage VDC. In order to improve the energy conversion efficiency, Guyomar et al. have proposed the SSHI technique (Badel et al., 2006; Guyomar et al., 2005). In this technique, a bidirectional switch and an inductor L are added in series with the piezoelectric element. The electric circuit of the SSHI with the rectifier is shown in Figure 1(b). The switch is conducted at each maximum and minimum of the displacement or at the zero crossing of the vibration velocity, in order to reverse the voltage across the piezoelectric element and put it in phase with velocity. The result is that the energy stored in the structural clamped capacitor CP is extracted by the LCp resonance and achieved to a minimum value, and thus, the piezoelectric voltage can be increased (Liang and Liao, 2011). The harvested energy of the system with the SSHI technique is similar to that using the standard interface under the strongly coupled condition (Shu et al., 2007). There are two SSHI structures: series and parallel connections. The series technique provides power for low values of load resistances R (first maximum of power; Figure 3). The parallel technique provides power for large values of load resistance R (second maximum; Figure 3). Figure 4(c) shows the theoretical waveforms of series SSHI. When the vibration velocity crosses zero, the switch is conducted, and the inductor L and the piezoelectric capacitor CP begin to oscillate. This resonant circuit increases the magnitude and changes the polarity of the voltage across the piezoelectric capacitance sinusoidally, and thus put voltage vp and velocity
u
·
in phase, which indicates that more energy is extracted from the vibration source.

To quantify the performances of energy harvesting devices, the force–displacement diagram is employed to illustrate the energy conversion cycle. In the case of a purely capacitive load on the piezoelectric element, the displacement and voltage are in phase; the area of the cycle is null, so the harvesting energy is equal to zero. When a resistive load is added, a phase shift appears between displacement and voltage (Figure 4(a)). Figure 5 shows the force–displacement locus under three conditions. The first condition corresponds to the simple resistive load. The area enclosed by the locus represents the vibratory energy converted into electrical energy. The second condition corresponds to the full-wave bridge rectifier. The extracted energy by the full-wave bridge is lower than in the case of simple resistance because the maximum piezoelectric voltage is lower, but the maximal value of the displacement remains the same. The third condition corresponds to the series SSHI technique. The energy harvested by the series SSHI technique is much higher than the previous cases because the LCp resonance increases the magnitude of vp in the low-coupling condition, which the magnitude of displacement does not vary.

sec.title: Bistable energy harvester
sec.p: The most piezoelectric energy harvesting system is a linear electromechanical device excited at resonance. Considering that most realistic vibration environments are more accurately described as multifrequency and time varying, narrowband linear systems are inefficient under these conditions. Nonlinear systems, on the other hand, are capable of responding over a broad frequency range. The solution is to use a bistable inertial oscillator comprises permanent magnets and a piezoelectric cantilever beam (Figure 1(c)). The bistable behavior is obtained with two magnets. One is mounted on the tip of the beam and the other one is fixed on a stage. Because the two magnets repulse to each other, the system will be a bistable system, and there will be two possible stable positions, as shown in Figure 6. When the distance between these two magnets is designed properly, the nonlinear behavior can broaden the available bandwidth (Lin et al., 2010; Stanton et al., 2010).

caption.p: Principle of the broadband energy harvesting device with a destabilized zero equilibrium position.

sec.p: The nonlinear magnetic repulsion force FM given by the interaction of the magnets can be simplified to one-dimensional model, and it is acting only in vertical direction (Stanton et al., 2010). The magnetic force FM(u) is a variable value and depends on the displacement of the cantilever beam u and the distance between the moving and the fixed magnets. Using the curve fitting method, the magnetic force FM for a specific distance can be expressed as equation (11) (Lin et al., 2010)
where a and b are the fitted parameters.

In order to analyze the nonlinear energy harvester with an electric interface, in this study, we adopt an electric equivalent impedance representation. According to equations (2), (3), and (11), the equivalent circuit model can be represented, as shown in Figure 7. The host structure with piezoelectric elements is modeled by the classical equivalent circuit. The magnetic force FM is taken into account by adding a nonlinear magnetic feedback loop. The main advantage of this equivalent circuit is that it can be easily simulated and does not need to use numerical methods. This method has some limitations. First of all, it considers the equivalent spring as a linear one in which the stiffness is independent of the position of the mass. In the present case, this is true only when the displacement is small with respect to the distance between the moving and the fixed magnets. When this hypothesis is not verified, significant errors can take place.

sec.title: Experimental setup
sec.p: In order to demonstrate the performances of the energy harvesting devices, a simple experimental test was performed on a clamped cantilever steel beam with 31-type lead zirconate titanate (PZT-QA) elements, provided by the Eleceram Technology Co., Ltd. There were two piezoelectric elements. The first one is the main element to harvest the energy, and it was connected to the SSHI interface. The second one is smaller in size, and it was used only to sense the velocity and to generate the driving signal for the switches of the SSHI interface (Chen et al., 2012). The electronic components in this experiment were supplied by an external DC source. A picture of the tested beam and SSHI circuit is shown in Figure 8, and the detailed experimental setup is presented in Figure 9. The distance between the two magnets was 3.5 mm. The dimensions of the beam and the piezoelectric elements are shown in Table 1. The beam was excited at the fixed end by an electromagnetic shaker (Brüel & Kjær 4809). The shaker is driven by a data acquisition card (NI-DAQ USB-6259). To realize the SSHI circuit, two diodes and two metal oxide semiconductor field effect transistor (MOSFET) switches were used. When the velocity signal goes zero crossing from negative to positive, the negative-channel metal oxide semiconductor (NMOS) switch (IRFU210) is switched-on, and when the signal goes zero crossing from positive to negative, the positive-channel metal oxide semiconductor (PMOS switch (IRF9640) is switched-on. The two diodes confine the current flow, and the inductor L resonates with the clamped capacitor CP of the piezoelectric element. Parameters of the model were identified from the experimental measurements. The tip displacement of the beam u was measured when the piezoelectric element is in open circuit and short circuit. The experimental test was performed on the linear and nonlinear clamped cantilever beams, as shown in Figure 9. The simulation was carried out with MATLAB and PSIM software packages, as shown in Figure 11. The module SimCoupler in PSIM software is used to make a link between SIMULINK in MATLAB and PSIM. The driving chirp frequency of the input force is sent from MATLAB to the electric circuit implemented in PSIM. The simulated results will be sent back to MATLAB and organized. Figures 12 and 13 show the experimental and simulation results of increasing frequency sweeping for the case of standard DC rectifier interface and SSHI interface, respectively. The experimental driving signal was chirping with frequency range from 5 to 30 Hz in 250 s. The simulation driving signal was ranging from 1 to 30 Hz in 300 s, and its sweeping rate was the same as the experimental conditions (ωS = 0.1 Hz/s). The sweeping rate was kept sufficiently small in order to reflect the nonlinear response (Nayfeh and Mook, 1979). The output voltage for the linear system without magnetic force and the output voltage for the case with the magnetic force are plotted in figure 12. The load resistance was chosen to be 2 MΩ to show the piezoelectric terminal voltage. Compared with the experimental results, the simulation shows good agreement with the experimental data. The results of Figures 12 and 13 show that the piezoelectric voltage vp at 10.4 Hz (resonant frequency in linear system) is almost the same for both the systems, but at nonresonance frequencies, the bistable system can improve the output power obviously. The nonlinear effect at the resonance is limited unlike in the nonresonant region. At the resonance, the driving force from resonant effect is larger than the magnetic force in our experiment, so the nonlinear magnetic coupling technique cannot work effectively. The results also show considerable chaotic motion when f < 5 Hz and between 10 and 17 Hz. For other frequencies, the motion is would-be periodic response. This result is in agreement with study in Stanton et al. (2010) and Thompson (1989). Over a wide frequency range, there is enough energy imparted into the bistable system to enable driving of the beam from one stable position to the other.

sec.p: In the nonlinear system, there is a critical frequency when the potential energy is not enough to drive the system from one stable position to the other stable position (Mann, 2009; Stewart et al., 1995). In our experimental results, as shown in Figures 12 and 13, the critical frequency is around 23 Hz. When the driving frequency is higher than 23 Hz, the piezoelectric terminal voltage in the nonlinear system is the same as that in the linear system.

sec.title: Work-cycle study
sec.p: Two specific frequencies (at-resonance frequency: f = 10.4 Hz and off-resonance frequency: f = 5 Hz) were chosen to be the examples to analyze the work cycles. Figures 14 and 15 show simulation results of the voltage vp across the piezoelectric element, the velocity, and the voltage–displacement diagrams at resonance frequency of the structure (10.4 Hz) for standard DC rectifier and SSHI technique. The maximum displacement is Umax = 2.5 mm. According to equation (9), the energy by period for the SSHI technique is ESSHI = 13.5 µJ, and thus, the power is PSSHI = 140.4 µW. According to equation (10), the Erec = 2.39 µJ and power for standard DC rectifier is Prec = 24.86 µW. Figures 16 and 17 show voltage vp across the piezoelectric element, the velocity and the voltage–displacement diagrams at nonresonance frequency of the structure (5 Hz) for standard DC rectifier and SSHI technique.

sec.p: Figures 14 to 17 clearly show that the SSHI interface enlarges the work-cycle area by increasing the piezoelectric voltage, and the nonlinear technique increase the work-cycle area by increasing displacement at nonresonance frequencies. Therefore, if we compare the energy harvested at the nonresonance frequency (Figures 16 and 17), the work-cycle area of the bistable device is much wider. This means that for both standard DC rectifier and series SSHI, the bistable device keeps good performances at the would-be resonance but increases them at the nonresonance.

Figure 18 shows the output power for the SSHI technique in the case of bistable and linear devices and for the two frequencies: at resonance frequency of 10.4 Hz and nonresonance frequency of 5 Hz. The maximum output power at resonance frequency (10.4 Hz) is 0.14 mW. This power at nonresonance frequency (5 Hz) with linear device is only 0.3 µW, but with bistable vibration, the output power is 8 µW. Comparing bistable system to linear system results, the output power close to the resonance frequency is almost the same, but more energy can be harvested in the bistable system at nonresonant frequency when the displacement is large enough to drive the beam from one stable position to the other stable position.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: This article studies the performances of magnetic nonlinear piezoelectric generator combined with a series SSHI interface in the weak coupling case. The equations of motion for a one-degree-of-freedom piezoelectric cantilever beam with magnetic nonlinear force were derived, and an equivalent electric circuit is proposed. Then, this equivalent electric circuit is used to simulate a bistable piezoelectric generator with the series SSHI technique. Finally, the nonlinear generator was tested experimentally and compared with work cycle to standard interface and linear technique. The SSHI technique has proved that it is an effective technique to improve output power over the standard interface in both linear and bistable cases. Moreover, the nonlinear coupling technique has proved that it is not only advantageous over linear technique for standard interface but also for SSHI interface. It is interesting to combine these two remarkable techniques, and the results show that these two techniques can work well together. The SSHI interface enlarges the work-cycle area by increasing the piezoelectric voltage in the weak coupling case, and the nonlinear technique increases the work-cycle area by increasing the displacement at nonresonance frequencies. According to the analysis of work cycles, the synchronized switching interface and nonlinear bistable technique are two major factors for designing a broad bandwidth and efficient energy harvester. Through these two nonlinear techniques, the piezoelectric harvester can work more efficiently, and more output power at a broadened frequency range can be gained.
